video.title: Python Online Multiplayer Game Development Tutorial
video.description:
This Python online game tutorial will show you how to code a scaleable multiplayer game with python using sockets/networking and pygame. You will learn how to deploy your game so that people anywhere around the world can play against each other.

You will learn and understand the following after this tutorial:
• How a Client/Server System Works
• How to Develop Applications to an External Server
• How to Code a Client
• How to Code a Server
• Sending Encrypted Data Such as Objects Over a Port
• Connecting Multiple Clients to a Server

💻Code: https://techwithtim.net/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/networkTutrorial.zip

⭐️ Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (0:00:51) 1 - Creating a Client Using Sockets
⌨️ (0:16:55) 2 - Creating a Server
⌨️ (0:34:04) 3 - Sending & Receiving Information From Server
⌨️ (0:44:43) 4 - Connecting Multiple Clients
⌨️ (1:03:38) 5 - Sending Objects With Pickle!
⌨️ (1:14:52) 6 - Online Rock Paper Scissors

🔗 How to Install Pygame: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AdUZArA-kZw

🔗 Pycharm Download: https://www.jetbrains.com/pycharm/

🎥 Tutorial from Tech with Tim. Check out his YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/techwithtim

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

And subscribe for new videos on technology: https://youtube.com/subscription_center?add_user=freecodecamp

topLevelComment.author: Cole Payne-sexton
topLevelComment.text:
for linux
python3 --version 
if it says python3 command not found then install python 3 with the following
sudo apt update && sudo apt upgrade -y  && sudo apt install python3 -y && sudo apt install python3-pip -y

at the next prompt (assuming no errors) run the following
python3 -m pip install tk && sudo apt install tk and python3 -m pip install pygame

replies.author: Cole Payne-sexton
replies.text: tk is a module that pygame uses that doesnt get installed with pygame, you can verify that it was installed by entering python3 (press enter) import tkinker

topLevelComment.author: K. Chris Caldwell
topLevelComment.text: For those having trouble running the required multiple files - server, client1, and client2 - in Visual Studio Code (VSC), open subsequent instances of VSC for each client file to run and then open and run the one client file in each instance, while running the server file in the main instance. Cool is that edits in the client file in the main VSC instance will automatically show up in the other open two instances.

replies.author: Bean Sprugget
replies.text: What I did was open multiple instances of powershell. So I did `python server.py`, then split the terminal to get a new instance, so I could run `python client.py`, and then do that again (and more as necessary for more clients).

replies.author: Harpreet06
replies.text: @Jack Petersen You still got this issue? Sorry for the late reply, I did this a while ago and moved on to other things. What he means is you have to open up a new Visual studio code program/instance (not a new tab, you have to click windows button and open another VSC) to run something else while the server file is running. If you just have 1 open then run the server file then click on a client file on a new tab and run that, nothing happens because that instance/program is constantly running server file and can't run anything else. So for the multiplayer game, you'll have 3 instances of VSC running, first the server file, then client 1 and the last one will have client 2 running.

topLevelComment.author: Mick Mickymick
topLevelComment.text:
This is not really a great tutorial. He basically just types everything out and keeps saying 'Don't worry, you'll understand it later', but he never actually explains anything later. Luckily most of the code is fairly self-explanatory.And some of that code is janky af. That line make_pos(read_pos) and then like a thousand brackets to convert a string to a tuple and back to a string.

Also nothing is commented so you have to do that all yourself but it also makes it impossible to come back to this code and re use it in future

On a more minor note, his names for variables are terrible 'p' and 'n' are basically textbook 'don't name your variables this' examples. Unfortunately this is the only tutorial like this I found so we have to make do.

topLevelComment.author: KP
topLevelComment.text:
Topic: Connecting Multiple Clients
As I understood the algorithm, the only way that the Client1 will receive an updated position of Client2 is when Client1 sends an update of his current position. So this means that if you are the Client1, you won't receive any updates of Client2 position if you did nothing (or did not send anything).

But on the demo that he did, Client1 was receiving an update position of Client2 even though it does not send anything. Why is that?

Thank you for anybody who can clarify this. Thaanks! :)

replies.author: Reflections
replies.text:
If I understood correctly: The clock on the server side is responsible for this update. The server clock checks for incoming data; and whenever it receives data from any client; it then sends position data to the other clients.

The key to understanding how this works is that there is only 1 server; but multiple clients. So the clients send information only at client function send which happens at keypress; but the server receives multiple sets of data because it receives data from more than one client. Therefore client 2 can trigger the send function on the server; which then gets sent to other clients.

topLevelComment.author: Bartosz Błachucki
topLevelComment.text: Thanks for the tutorial. I just want to mention that using built in names as variable names is a bad practice.  Maybe this example is trivial but when You write str.split() You can make someone wonder whether You're using a static method of str class or a method of some class instance named str. What's really neat is that Pycharm was actually telling You that name "str" shadows built-in name 'str' (that's why it's underlined in the video). @EDIT : I know that the author probably knows about it by now but maybe someone else doesn't

replies.author: Jae
replies.text:
I had made the mistake of saving the port variable as a string when it's suppose to be an integer. So you never recieved the string/byte object from the server, hence the 'NoneType'
Check if you have saved the port as a string not an int

topLevelComment.author: Bartosz Błachucki
topLevelComment.text:
SOCK_STREAM means that it is a TCP socket.

SOCK_DGRAM means that it is a UDP socket.

replies.author: Louzy Nerd
replies.text: Andrija Jovanovic thx man 👍

replies.author: Andrija Jovanovic
replies.text:
@Louzy Nerd internet protocols TCP-Transmission Controll Protocol and UDP is User Datagram Protocol.
 TCP is connection oriented − once a connection is established, data can be sent bidirectional, while UDP is a simpler, connectionless Internet protocol, messages are sent as packets.

topLevelComment.author: Ballistic_Bazooka
topLevelComment.text:
Thanks for the video, it was very helpful. Can someone tell me how you can send multiple objects through a server. I've been making a shooter game for a school project and have been trying to send player objects as well as projectile objects but I don't know how to do it. Please it will be a lot of help if someone could help me, I've been trying for months.


Edit: I managed to fix the issue

replies.author: Ballistic_Bazooka
replies.text: @André Fernandes Thanks for the reply. I managed to find the actual problem with my program which was when sending multiple objects from a server, they may not arrive at the same time causing an error. I fixed this by sending everything in one dictionary (cuz i couldn't be bothered to set up a buffer or smt similar). Thanks for the advice tho

replies.author: André Fernandes
replies.text:
Maybe it's already solved, but you can use the Pickle standard library to encode/decode the object. 

pickle.dumps(object) should encode
pickle.loads(object) should decode

topLevelComment.author: Arush James

replies.author: Iñigo
replies.text: Threading is like thread wrapped with a nice bow. It's easier and more convenient to use. Thread isn't meant to be used by normal python code, but it's used by threading.

replies.author: VenomBlade Gaming
replies.text: I think those are 2 different libraries. Im pretty sure either or works as long as you write everything correctly but for this video, just follow what he does

topLevelComment.author: Abhishek shah
topLevelComment.text: 26:16 : Can you please explain what start_new_thread(threaded_client, (conn,)) is doing and why is there a comma after conn argument? I believe it is a function buy you haven't defined it anywhere and it still works and I can't figure it out ! Help much appreciated!

replies.author: Doggo
replies.text: Cause it's a tuple. A single item tuple needs to have a comma afterwards due to the parsing from the interpreter.

replies.author: Sheppsu
replies.text: start_new_thread is a function from "_thread"
